一位了解谈判情况的消息人士称，以色列和哈马斯之间旨在缓和加沙战斗的卡塔尔斡旋谈判周六仍在继续，尽管以色列加大了对加沙飞地的攻击力度。

消息人士告诉路透社，谈判并未破裂，但进展速度比周五晚上​​升级之前“慢得多”。由于谈判的敏感性，该消息人士要求匿名。

周六，被围困的加沙人民几乎与外界没有任何联系，以色列战机向哈马斯统治的巴勒斯坦飞地投下更多炸弹，军方领导人表示，长期威胁的地面进攻正在酝酿之中。

卡塔尔已经进行了三周多的幕后外交，与哈马斯官员和以色列对话，以促进和平并确保人质获释。

上周的调解导致两名美国人质、一对母女和两名以色列老年妇女获释。

以色列称，该伊斯兰组织的袭击造成 1,400 人死亡，其中大部分是平民，224 名人质被俘，其中许多人持有来自 25 个不同国家的外国护照。

过去三周，以色列对加沙的轰炸和袭击比以往任何时候都更加猛烈，巴勒斯坦卫生当局表示，以色列的袭击已导致哈马斯控制的加沙地带 7000 多名巴勒斯坦人死亡。

卡塔尔是一个规模虽小但富有的能源和投资强国，有着雄心勃勃的外交政策目标，与哈马斯有着直接的沟通渠道，哈马斯在多哈设有政治办公室。卡塔尔特使此前曾帮助调解该伊斯兰组织与以色列之间的休战。

迪拜新闻编辑室的报道和写作；大卫·埃文斯编辑; Sat, 28 Oct 2023 20:02:27 GMT THRJHU5U3VMHNLN3KPF5ZHV7FU https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/qatar-led-negotiations- Between-israel-hamas-continue-source-2023-10-28/Reuters以色列巴勒斯坦/卡塔尔（更新 1） Israel launches Gaza war's second phase with ground operation, Netanyahu saysSummary:
  • 最新进展：
  • 内塔尼亚胡说：“我们将消灭地上和地下的敌人”
  • 一位加沙记者在恐怖之夜后说道：“上帝保佑瓦砾下的任何人”

以色列总理本杰明·内塔尼亚胡周六表示，以色列军队在对哈马斯武装分子采取地面行动时发动了加沙战争的第二阶段，并发誓要“消灭地上和地下的敌人”。

随着以色列战机向哈马斯统治的巴勒斯坦飞地投下更多炸弹，加沙地带被围困的人们几乎与外界没有任何联系，军事领导人表示，长期威胁的地面进攻正在酝酿之中。

内塔尼亚胡在特拉维夫举行的新闻发布会上警告说，这场战争将是“漫长而艰难的”，并重申以色列呼吁巴勒斯坦平民撤离以色列集中攻击的加沙地带北部。

他誓言将尽一切努力营救被哈马斯扣押的200多名人质。

内塔尼亚胡对记者说：“这是战争的第二阶段，其目标很明确——摧毁哈马斯的执政和军事能力，并将人质带回家。”

“我们才刚刚开始，”他说。 “我们将消灭地上和地下的敌人。”

10 月 7 日，伊斯兰组织哈马斯发动袭击，造成 1,400 名以色列人死亡，这是该国 75 年历史上死亡人数最多的一天，之后以色列封锁并轰炸了加沙地带三周。

西方国家普遍支持以色列的自卫权，但国际社会对爆炸造成的人员伤亡越来越关注，要求暂停向加沙平民提供援助的呼声也越来越高。

拥有 230 万人口的加沙地带卫生当局表示，在以色列消灭武装分子的行动中，有 7,650 名巴勒斯坦人被杀。

巴勒斯坦总统马哈茂德·阿巴斯领导的巴勒斯坦权力机构管理着被占领的约旦河西岸部分地区，而哈马斯则统治着加沙。 ”。

由于许多建筑物化为废墟，难以找到住所，加沙人缺乏食物、水、燃料和药品。从周五晚上开始，他们的困境变得更加严重，当时电话和互联网服务被切断，随后整夜遭到猛烈轰炸。

一位加沙记者说：“上帝保佑瓦砾下的任何人。”他在大楼楼梯上度过了一个可怕的夜晚，看着炸弹落下的“火带”，以色列军队似乎与巴勒斯坦武装分子交火。

他说，如果没有手机，就没有人可以叫救护车，而且紧急服务也缺乏燃料。绝望的人们一旦找到警察，就会使用对讲机寻求帮助。

以色列首席军事发言人拒绝透露以色列是否是加沙电信中断的幕后黑手，但表示将采取必要措施保护其军队。

以色列军队瞄准隧道

尽管没有迹象表明大规模入侵，但以色列表示，周五晚上派往加沙的部队仍在现场，重点关注基础设施，包括哈马斯修建的广泛隧道网络。

以色列在呼吁加沙人向南迁移时表示，哈马斯躲在民用建筑下，特别是在北部。巴勒斯坦人表示，没有地方是安全的，炸弹还摧毁了人口稠密地区南部的房屋。

联合国秘书长安东尼奥·古特雷斯表示：“一场人道主义灾难正在我们眼前展开。”

全球多个援助机构表示，他们无法联系到加沙的工作人员。但加沙红十字与红新月国际委员会的一名代表收到了一条音频信息。

威廉·朔姆伯格说，医护人员正在全天候工作，同时也在处理个人悲剧。在红十字国际委员会在 X 上发布的一段视频中，他对 BBC 广播公司表示：“我与一位前一天晚上失去兄弟和表弟的医生进行了交谈。”

亿万富翁企业家埃隆·马斯克提供了他的星链卫星网络，为国际公认的援助组织提供加沙通信支持。

来自以色列一侧戒备森严的围栏的视频显示，加沙的爆炸在一排被毁的建筑物中冒出浓烟。

哈马斯周六表示，本来准备就加沙 200 多名人质问题与以色列达成协议，但以色列对此“停滞不前”。

以色列军方发言人驳斥了这些报道，称哈马斯“愤世嫉俗”地试图影响公众舆论。内塔尼亚胡表示，即使在加沙发动地面进攻期间，也将继续进行接触以确保人质获释。

一位了解谈判情况的消息人士称，由卡塔尔调解的以色列和哈马斯之间旨在缓和加沙战斗的谈判周六继续进行，但速度要慢得多。

报告称，喷气式飞机击毙了哈马斯空中部队负责人阿西姆·阿布·拉卡巴（Asem Abu Rakaba），他是 10 月 7 日袭击事件的关键人物。

地区“定时炸弹”

战机袭击了加沙北部 150 个地下目标，包括哈马斯隧道、地下作战空间和其他地下基础设施，造成该组织其他人死亡。

哈马斯的武装派别卡萨姆旅表示，其武装分子正在加沙东北部城镇拜特哈农和布赖吉中部地区与以色列军队作战。

声明称：“卡萨姆旅和所有巴勒斯坦抵抗力量已做好充分准备，全力对抗侵略并挫败入侵。”

美国和其他西方国家敦促以色列暂缓发动地面进攻，因为担心巴勒斯坦人伤亡惨重，冲突扩大。

哈马斯得到伊朗的支持，伊朗也支持黎巴嫩、叙利亚、伊拉克和也门的民兵组织。美国军队在伊拉克和叙利亚受到伊朗支持的组织的攻击。华盛顿一直在向该地区转移更多军事资产。

加兰特告诉记者，以色列无意将战争扩大到加沙以外，但已在各方面做好准备。

以色列军方报告周六在与黎巴嫩边境发生新的交火，这是自 2006 年以来最严重的边境冲突中的最新一起。

周六，这场危机在欧洲、中东和亚洲各地的城市吸引了数十万亲巴勒斯坦示威者。

“这与哈马斯无关。这是为了保护巴勒斯坦人的生命，”伦敦的游行者卡米尔·雷韦尔塔说。

当被问及以色列是否在周五晚上开始的地面攻势开始时摧毁了移动服务时，海军少将丹尼尔·哈加里说：

“我们会尽一切努力确保我们的部队安全，无论是暂时的还是永久的，只要我们需要，我们不会对此多说什么。”

埃及外交部周六表示，包括卡车检查程序在内的“以色列障碍”阻碍了通过埃及和巴勒斯坦飞地之间的拉法过境点向加沙地带迅速运送援助物资。

“卡车在前往拉法口岸之前必须在以色列尼扎纳口岸接受检查，在真正进入拉法口岸之前需要行驶 100 公里（62 英里）的距离，这会造成障碍，严重延迟援助物资的抵达，”该部发言人在一份声明中说。

拉法过境点由埃及控制，不与以色列接壤，自以色列为报复哈马斯武装分子10月7日从沿海地带发动袭击而封锁加沙以来，拉法过境点已成为运送援助物资的主要地点。

联合国秘书长安东尼奥·古特雷斯周五表示，冲突发生前，每天约有 500 辆卡车进入加沙，但最近几天，平均每天只有 12 辆卡车进入加沙。

以色列誓言要消灭统治加沙的哈马斯组织，据称该组织在 10 月 7 日对以色列南部发动的袭击中杀害了 1,400 人，并劫持了数百人质。

周六，被围困的加沙人民几乎与外界没有任何联系，以色列战机投下了更多炸弹，并暗示对哈马斯长期威胁的地面进攻即将开始。巴勒斯坦当局称已有 7,000 多人被杀。

根据周六的最新政府数据，本周早些时候墨西哥太平洋度假城市阿卡普尔科遭受五级飓风奥蒂斯造成的破坏，造成的死亡人数已上升至 39 人。

周三早些时候，奥蒂斯以每小时 165 英里（266 公里）的风袭击了阿卡普尔科，导致城市被洪水淹没，房屋、商店和酒店的屋顶被撕裂，车辆被淹没，通讯以及道路和空中连接被切断。

迄今为止，政府几乎没有公布有关死伤者的信息，此前曾报告称，奥蒂斯造成 27 人死亡，另有 4 人失踪。

安全部长罗莎·伊塞拉·罗德里格斯表示，目前有 10 人下落不明。

自从破纪录的风暴导致数千名居民难以获得食物和水以来，阿卡普尔科遭受了抢劫。

许多人抱怨政府对阿卡普尔科的援助不足，一些官员私下表达了对死亡人数可能上升的担忧。

根据阿卡普尔科所在格雷罗州政府的官方声明，修订后的死亡人数包括 29 名男性和 10 名女性。

报告称，超过 220,000 户家庭和 80% 的酒店业受到影响，超过 513,000 人断电。

奥蒂斯造成的破坏造成的损失估计达数十亿美元，并派出 8,000 多名武装部队人员前往帮助受灾港口恢复重建。

墨西哥当局表示，奥蒂斯是有史以来袭击墨西哥太平洋海岸的最强风暴。它让预报员措手不及，在上岸前就以意想不到的速度积聚力量，超出了最初的预测。

匈牙利政府以部分照片中含有 LGBT 内容为由，禁止 18 岁以下青少年参观在布达佩斯举办的世界新闻摄影展。

总理维克托·欧尔班 (Viktor Orban) 的民族主义政府推行基督教保守派议程，并于 2021 年禁止在 18 岁以下青少年阅读的书籍和电影中“展示和宣传同性恋”，尽管遭到权利组织和欧盟的强烈批评。

匈牙利国家博物馆表示，在极右翼米哈赞克/我们的祖国党发起政府调查后，匈牙利国家博物馆周六停止出售青少年摄影展门票。

极右翼政党告诉国家通讯社 MTI：“根据 Mi Hazank 的倡议，18 岁以下的青少年不得参观国家博物馆的展览，因为这违反了儿童保护法。”新规则于周六晚些时候发布在博物馆的网站上。

展览组织者和政府发言人没有回复路透社通过电子邮件提出的问题。

今年早些时候，一些匈牙利书商因销售描绘同性恋的书籍而被罚款，这些书籍没有按照立法要求用塑料包装。

政府称 2021 年法律旨在保护儿童，但它引起了 LGBT 群体的焦虑。

乌克兰总统泽伦斯基周六敦促 60 多名国家安全顾问召开会议，根据他的与俄罗斯和平的 10 点公式制定一个全球模式。

这次会议在中立的马耳他闭门举行，将有助于衡量乌克兰和西方在以色列冲突占据头条新闻、将焦点从基辅转移之际争取持续和更广泛支持的能力。

泽连斯基表示，他渴望有一天人类历史“只是和平的历史”。他说，国际法和《联合国宪章》阐明了这一愿望。

“但是《联合国宪章》有效吗？”他在 YouTube 上分享的英文地址中问道。

“在这里，在乌克兰、中东和非洲国家，这个问题的答案是母亲埋葬在战争中丧生的儿女的哭声，以及因战争而成为孤儿的绝望。

A US Army reservist accused of spraying a bowling alley and bar with gunfire in Lewiston, Maine, killing 18 people, was found dead from a self-inflicted gunshot wound in a recycling plant trailer after a 48-hour manhunt, police said on Saturday.

The body of Robert R. Card, 40, was discovered on Friday night at a recycling plant in Lisbon Falls where he worked at one point, less than a mile from where police had found his abandoned getaway vehicle shortly after his shooting spree on Wednesday night.

A Maine State Police tactical team discovered Card's body in an unlocked trailer in an overflow parking lot of the recycling plant, Maine Public Safety Commissioner Mike Sauschuck told reporters on Saturday.

Officers had cleared the plant twice in the course of their search, Sauschuck said, as they believed Card had some "employment relation" to the business, but had missed the extra parking lot, where about 60 box trailers full of crushed plastic and metal were parked, he said.

The body was found in an unlocked trailer, dressed in what appeared to be the same brown sweatshirt the suspect was wearing the night of the attack. Investigators would not comment on how long they believed it had been there.

Officials said they recovered a long rifle in Card's abandoned white Subaru and two guns on his body, without confirming the makes and models. All the weapons were apparently purchased by Card legally, a representative for the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives said.

A total of 18 people were killed and 13 others were wounded in Wednesday night's carnage, which began when the gunman opened fire with a rifle inside the Just-In-Time Recreation bowling alley, then launched another attack minutes later at Schemengees Bar & Grille Restaurant a few miles away.

Three people were still in critical condition, Sauschuck said on Saturday.

MOTIVE INVESTIGATION

Officials have not confirmed a possible motive for the violence, and were digging through cell phone records, following up on hundreds of tips and going through about a dozen search warrants this weekend to learn more, Sauschuck said.

Based on the investigation so far, Sauschuck said there was "a mental health component" to the tragedy. He said there was evidence Card was paranoid and "felt like people were talking about him," which might have led him to target those specific venues.

A Maine law enforcement bulletin circulated earlier this week identified Card as a trained firearms instructor at the US Army Reserve base in Saco, Maine. It said he had been hearing voices and had other mental health issues.

He threatened to shoot up the National Guard base in Saco and was "reported to have been committed to mental health facility for two weeks during summer 2023 and subsequently released," according to the bulletin from the Maine Information & Analysis Center, a unit of Maine State Police.

However, Sauschuck said on Saturday that officials had no evidence so far that Card had been "forcibly committed" for mental illness treatment, and were still looking into any voluntary treatment Card might have received.

Sauschuck said police found a note left at Card's house, addressed to a loved one, which listed the passcode to his phone and bank account information.

"I wouldn't describe it as an explicit suicide note, but the tone and tenor was that the individual was not going to be around," he said.

The shootings and prolonged manhunt terrorized the normally bustling but serene community of Lewiston, a former textile hub and the second-most populous city in Maine. It lies on the banks of the Androscoggin River, about 35 miles (56 km) north of the state's largest city, Portland.

Many business owners in Lewiston and adjacent communities closed shop in the immediate aftermath of the shooting, while authorities shuttered schools and ordered some 40,000 area residents to shelter in place as a precaution.

Within hours of Wednesday night's bloodshed, police circulated surveillance camera photos from one of the crime scenes of a bearded man wearing a brown, hooded sweatshirt and jeans and carrying what appeared to be a semi-automatic rifle.

The initial trail of clues led to Lisbon, about 7 miles (11 km) to the southeast of Lewiston, where Maine State Police found a white SUV they believed Card had abandoned at a boat launch on the river. Lisbon Falls, where Card was found dead, is the next town along the river.

As part of their search for Card, police trawled the waters of the Androscoggin River with divers and sonar on Friday, and sent teams of officers door-to-door in neighborhood canvasses seeking additional clues and possible eyewitnesses.

The slain victims included four deaf people who had been competing in a beanbag-tossing tournament at the bar and grill, a father-and-son pair of bowlers, a part-time bowling alley worker who tried to confront the shooter with a knife, and an elderly couple aged 76 and 73.

One police officer was killed in Bangladesh on Saturday and over 100 people injured during an opposition party protest demanding the resignation of Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina and calling for a free and fair vote under a caretaker government.

Police fired tear gas and rubber bullets as clashes erupted when tens of thousands of supporters of the opposition Bangladesh Nationalist Party (BNP) gathered in the capital Dhaka, chanting slogans against the government.

Dozens of vehicles, including police vans and ambulances, were set on fire, police and media said.

Dhaka Metropolitan Police spokesman Faruq Hossain told reporters one officer had been killed and 41 others were injured in clashes with protesters.

Several journalists were attacked and injured while trying to cover the clashes, media reports said.

Security was tightened in the city in recent days as thousands of people arrived to attend the rally. Hundreds of opposition party activists have been arrested, BNP leaders said.

The party has been calling on Hasina to resign to allow elections scheduled in January to be held under a neutral caretaker government - a demand her government has so far rejected.

"Today's rally continued for hours in a perfectly disciplined and peaceful manner until all of a sudden the lobbing of tear gas shells started," senior BNP leader Abdul Moyeen Khan told Reuters.

"The intensity increased and violent attacks with sounds of blasts and shootings turned the whole place into a war zone."

The BNP has called for a dawn-to-dusk countrywide strike in protest against the police action.

"I came to protest the enforced disappearances, murders, and oppression that we have suffered for the past 15 years. This government is not safe anymore for even a second," BNP supporter Arif Khan said.

Hasina, who has maintained tight control since coming to power in 2009, has been accused of authoritarianism, human rights violations, cracking down on free speech and suppressing dissent while jailing her critics.

Her government is under pressure from the Western countries to hold "free and fair" elections.

In May, Washington said it would impose visa sanctions on Bangladeshis who undermine the democratic process at home, after accusations of vote-rigging and suppressing the opposition marred elections in 2014 and 2018. Hasina's government has denied the charges.

本周，墨西哥城市阿卡普尔科遭受奥蒂斯飓风袭击，这座标志性的海滩度假胜地遭到抢劫，这场创纪录的风暴造成至少 27 人死亡，数千名居民难以获取食物和水。

Otis pounded Acapulco with winds of 165 miles per hour (266 km per hour) early on Wednesday, flooding the city, tearing roofs from homes, stores and hotels, submerging vehicles, and severing communications as well as road and air connections.

The cost of devastation left by the Category 5 storm was estimated at billions of dollars , and over 8,000 armed forces members were sent to help the stricken port recover.

"Right now, money's no use to us because there's nothing to buy, everything's been looted," 57-year-old Acapulco resident Rodolfo Villagomez said after Otis tore through the city. "It was total chaos. You could hear it here hissing like a bull."

On Thursday evening, people carried off goods including food, water and toilet paper from stores. "We came to get food, because we don't have any," a woman told Reuters.

Reuters video showed people carrying boxes from a wrecked supermarket and loading up cars. Inside, shelves were bare.

"There were acts of looting in some places because there was an emergency," President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador said on Friday, urging residents not to take advantage of the situation.

Elsewhere, household detritus was littered among ruined deck chairs and jumbles of mangled trees outside wrecked homes.

Speaking at a regular press conference, Lopez Obrador said the government would help people in the city of nearly 900,000 in the southern state of Guerrero, one of Mexico's poorest.

But many residents said the aid was insufficient.

"All the stores are closed or destroyed," said Raul Busto Ramirez, 76, an engineer who works at Acapulco's airport. He blamed looting on shortages and said ATM machines were out of action, leaving people with no cash.

The government has released little information about dead and injured, saying only that four people are also missing. Some officials privately express concern the death toll will rise.

Letitia Murphy said she began to worry when she lost contact with her ex-husband and father of her two children, 59-year-old Briton Neil Marshall, who was in Acapulco when Otis hit.

Murphy said she found out on social media he had died after residents discovered his body close to where he was staying.

"We can't even get information about him," she told Reuters by phone. "It's horrible that we don't know what to do."

The Mexican and British governments did not immediately respond to requests for comment.

Another weather front that could produce more heavy rain is expected to gain strength off Central America in the coming days, again moving toward southern Mexico.

'WE WERE LUCKY'

Mexican authorities said Otis was the most powerful storm ever to strike Mexico's Pacific coast. It caught forecasters by surprise, gathering strength with unexpected speed before it came ashore, and surpassed initial predictions.

Still, Lopez Obrador said: "We were lucky."

"Nature, the creator protected us, even with the fury of the hurricane," he added. "There's a lot of material damage but luckily we're not registering too many deaths."

To evacuate tourists, an air bridge between Acapulco and Mexico City was being set up on Friday after authorities got the city's battered airport back up and running.

The government has yet to estimate the cost of Otis, but Enki Research, which tracks tropical storms and models the cost of their damage, saw it likely "approaching $15 billion." Lopez Obrador urged insurance companies to speed up payouts .

Governments sent messages of solidarity to Mexico, and Pope Francis expressed his condolences on Friday.

US President Joe Biden expressed his condolences for the hurricane's victims in a brief statement on Friday evening, pledging "full support" to Mexico's government as well as help ensuring US citizens in the area are safe.

State power utility CFE said on Friday it had restored 50% of the electricity service in Guerrero and Mexican telecommunications company America Movil had re-established nearly 60% of cell service.

Jeff, a 65-year-old Canadian in Acapulco, said he was stuck in the city and worried how he would survive the coming days because "all the stores have been pillaged."

"The disaster here is unbelievable," he said. "We don't see nothing happening except people trying to scavenge everything they can to survive for the next couple of weeks or months."

The Palestinian health ministry said on Saturday 7,650 people had been killed and 19,450 injured in Gaza since Israel's bombardment began. It said 70% of the dead there and in the West Bank, were women, children or the elderly.

'DISCONNECTED FROM THE WORLD'

The UN World Food Programme, World Health Organization and other agencies, as well as independent aid groups including Medecins Sans Frontieres and the Norwegian Refugee Council were among those saying they had lost contact with staff in Gaza.

Several humanitarian groups said Israel had deliberately cut off communications to the strip. The Israeli military did not immediately respond to a request for comment. Reuters has been unable to independently verify what was causing the blackout.

"The Israeli authorities have cut off landline, cellular, and internet communications, severely affecting our essential emergency medical services," said the Palestine Red Crescent Society on social media plaform X, without citing evidence.

For media organisations including Reuters, the inability to maintain regular contact with teams in Gaza underlined concerns over the safety of their staff and made it much harder to report comprehensively on what was happening.

The Israeli military says it does not deliberately target journalists but cannot guarantee their safety in Gaza.

"The shelling was intense everywhere in the strip," one Reuters reporter wrote in a message to colleagues, one of the few able to be sent by the Reuters team inside Gaza on Saturday.

Gaza-based freelance photographer Mohammed Zaanoun, speaking from inside the strip in a video he posted on social media on Saturday morning, said this might be the last video he uploaded.

"I have driven a long way to reach the border with Egypt to be able to send you this message and tell you that Gaza has been disconnected from the world," he said.

A year after 159 Halloween revellers were killed in a crowd crush in South Korea, the capital's night-life district of Itaewon was quiet on Saturday, the area's usual festivities replaced by mourning for those died.

In the days before Halloween, seasonal decorations normally adorn the alleys that house the district's hottest nightclubs and bars, but this year posters and flowers commemorating the dead took their place, and young people celebrated elsewhere.

Lee Sung-min, who has lived and worked in the Seoul district for years, said he did not even realise it was the Halloween weekend until early Saturday.

"It used to be filled with visitors dressed in costumes and blood makeup by this time. But if you look at the age range of the people walking around, it's mostly just relatively old local residents," Lee said.

The crowd surge last year led to the crush in a narrow alley in Itaewon, a disaster that many people in Seoul blamed on a lack of preparation and crowd control measures, with early calls for help going unanswered. Most of the people who died were aged in their 20s and 30s.

"I've left a note telling (the victims) not to lose courage and rest in peace," said Lee Jung-hyeop, who visited Itaewon to mark the anniversary.

Gatherings have not been banned in Itaewon over Halloween this year though authorities and police were conducting crowd-control drills featuring an AI-backed network of nearly 1,000 closed-circuit TV cameras, ahead of the first anniversary of the disaster.

Many people were still looking for other places to join Halloween festivities, such as Hongdae, another popular spot among the young.

"I thought Hongdae would be better than Itaewon to celebrate Halloween with my boyfriend," said Cheon Ye-ji, a 19-year-old student. "It looks like the crowd is better controlled after last year's incident."

The Itaewon deaths shocked a nation still scarred by the 2014 sinking of a ferry, the Sewol, that killed 304 people including 250 students on a school trip.

Last year's tragedy prompted a police investigation that ended in an acknowledgement of negligence and a poor response by the authorities, referring 23 officials for prosecution , but no senior government officials have resigned or been removed over the disaster.

在中国外交部长王毅与美国高级外交官在华盛顿进行了数小时的会晤后，美国官员周五表示，美国和中国已同意共同努力，推动拜登总统和习近平总统下个月举行峰会。

这是中国外长自 2018 年以来首次访问华盛顿，资深外交官王毅也与拜登进行了一个小时的会面，白宫称这次会谈是保持两个地缘政治对手之间沟通渠道畅通的“好机会”。政策差异。

美国官员表示，王毅与美国国务卿布林肯和国家安全顾问杰克·沙利文的会面历时两天，总计九个小时，并称这些互动“坦诚而深入”。

拜登的高级助手提出了华盛顿的主要关切：恢复两国之间军事渠道的必要性、北京在东海和南海的行动、台湾、人权、芬太尼前体的流动以及在美国被拘留的美国人案件。美国官员称，中国。

布林肯和王之间还就中东爆发的冲突进行了“坦诚的交流”。

似乎显示出一些积极势头的关键领域是拜登和习近平预计将于下个月在旧金山举行的亚太经合组织（APEC）峰会期间举行会晤。

一位不愿透露姓名的高级政府官员向记者介绍说：“我们正在为这样的会议做准备。”这位官员表示：“显然，中国领导人经常会公开确认即将进行的访问，因此我将让中方决定是否以及何时宣布这一消息。”

根据中国外交部的一份简短声明，王告诉拜登，他此行的目的是“着眼于旧金山”，帮助“遏制”美中关系的下滑，但没有透露任何细节。

外交部通报王毅与布林肯和沙利文会晤的消息称，“双方同意共同努力，促成两国元首在旧金山举行会晤”。

王毅在会见拜登时表示，中方重视美方稳定和改善美中关系的愿望。

拜登政府认为，与习近平的领导人直接接触对于管理紧张局势尤为重要，因为它试图防止关系陷入冲突。

这位美国官员表示：“潜在会议的一个重要部分将是两位领导人坐在一起，就战略意图进行对话。”

周四，王告诉布林肯，两国存在分歧，需要“深入”和“全面”对话，以减少误解并稳定关系。王说：“我们不仅应该恢复对话，而且对话应该深入、全面。”

在王毅为期三天的访问之前，近几个月主要应美国要求进行了一系列双边外交接触，旨在挽救年初美国击落所谓的中国间谍气球后迅速恶化的两国关系。

但华盛顿的一些人质疑，过去六个月美国内阁级官员对北京进行的一系列几乎没有回应的正式访问，包括布林肯、财政部长珍妮特·耶伦和商务部长吉娜·雷蒙多，是否对北京有利。

耶伦和雷蒙多的出访促成了新的双边经济和商业工作组的成立，批评人士担心，这只会将美国的注意力从制裁、出口管制和旨在加强美国与中国竞争的更广泛措施上转移，甚至可能推迟。

美国官员坚称，加强外交并不意味着放松政策。

对中东的担忧

以色列与哈马斯的冲突给超级大国之间紧张的关系增添了新的动力，华盛顿希望北京能够利用其对伊朗的影响力，防止中东地区的战争升级为更广泛的战争。

美国官员表示，这个问题在王毅的会议上经常被提及，但目前尚不清楚华盛顿是否能够让北京方面承诺利用其影响力帮助遏制冲突。

另一位政府高级官员表示：“我们对局势表示深切关注，并敦促中国采取更具建设性的做法，其中当然包括与伊朗人接触，以敦促各方保持冷静。”

中国谴责冲突中针对平民的暴力和袭击，虽然王宣称以色列的行动“超出自卫范围”，但他在评论中没有点名哈马斯。

第二名官员表示，布林肯提出了美国对中国最近在南海和东海的行动的担忧，包括“危险且非法地阻碍”菲律宾在南海仁爱礁的补给任务，以及不安全拦截菲律宾的补给任务。一架美国飞机。
